awd_titl_txt: IDBR: Type A - An unmanned aerial radio tracking system for monitoring small wildlife species
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Northern Arizona University to develop a new Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) system that integrates a radio telemetry receiver and data processing system for efficient detection and localization of tiny wildlife radio telemetry tags. The complete design, including parts, assembly plans, software, and training modules for the UAV-­RT system will be open sourced for widespread adoption of the technology, with dissemination and outreach by a user community website and demonstrations at wildlife conferences. The UAV-­RT system will also be disseminated to the public via media outreach, participation in community events, and collaboration with the Upward Bound Program at NAU to engage low-­ income rural high school students. The development goals of this program target rapid and widespread adoption of the technology by the biological and ecological research communities to enable new paradigms of field research with small wildlife species. The technology will benefit both scientific research and society by quickly improving the ability to understand the geographic distributions and habitat needs of many animal species.

Current methods of locating and tracking small tagged animals are hampered by the inaccessibility of their habitats. The high costs, risk to human safety, and small sample sizes resulting from current radio telemetry methods limit the understanding of the movement and behaviors of many species. UAV-­based technologies promise to revolutionize a range of ecological field study paradigms due to the ability of a sensing platform to fly in close proximity to rough terrain at very low cost. The new UAV-­based radio telemetry (UAV-­RT) system will dramatically improve wildlife tracking capability while using inexpensive, commercially available radio tags. The system design will reflect the unique needs of wildlife tracking applications, including easy assembly and repair in the field and reduction of fire risk. A team of engineers and wildlife ecologists from Northern Arizona University and Cornell University will design and build the prototype system and conduct field deployments to demonstrate and improve its performance.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this research was to develop an integrated open-source system for detecting small wildlife from an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV). While small, lightweight, and reliable, the very high frequency tags used on many wildlife are challenging to detect in the field and often require significant time and effort to localize after deployment. The primary goal was to improve the range of detection and decrease the time and labor required to scan an area for deployed tags. An additional goal was to disseminate this platform in a way that enabled other groups to build and deploy their own systems.

The research effort resulted in several key outcomes. Initial efforts involved developing conceptual vehicles and signal processing methods for beacon detection. A prototype system was built that integrated commercial off-the-shelf UAV components along with an on-board single-board computer for signal recording. The assembly plans, software, installation guides, and operational instructions were all documented on the project website and in public Github repositories. In addition to vehicle software and hardware, the team developed an extensive software interface that enabled vehicle configuration, radio system control, data transfer, data processing, and mapping of received radio signals. As part of these efforts, the team developed a novel method of signal bearing estimation based on principal component analysis (PCA) that proved robust and significantly decreased bearing errors compared to those measured by human wildlife trackers. This bearing estimation technique was integrated into the larger software architecture to allow for the estimation of tag position. These techniques were shown to significantly decrease localization errors when compared to localization estimates made with traditional manual analog-radio techniques. 

In addition to the applied developments, research was also conducted on methods of improved and automated UAV design. Multi-rotor aircraft design is often an iterative process of component selection, payload and flight time estimation, and iteration. In order to expedite and improve this design process, the team developed a genetic-algorithm multi-rotor design software that selected vehicle components based on required payload and flight time requirements. 

To broaden the impact of this research, outreach to local and regional public through high school STEM programs and community events was proposed to highlight the research and impacts on engineering design and scientific discovery. Throughout the duration of this project the research team participated in the annual Flagstaff Festival of Science and Flagstaff STEM Nights. The team also developed and taught a program for the Upward Bound Program at Northern Arizona University, contributing to the education and college preparation of high school students who will be first-generation college graduates and/or are from disadvantaged backgrounds.


Last Modified: 06/21/2022
Modified by: Michael W Shafer

Image
  • The UAV-RT system being tested outside of Flagstaff, Arizona. The directional antenna can be seen mounted below the UAV with data processing unit mounted above.
    Michael W. Shafer
    Public Domain
    Michael W Shafer
    UAV-RT Testing
